sentences: Lazer Lloyd (born Lloyd Paul Blumen; May 7, 1966) is an American singer, songwriter, and guitarist.
Lloyd was born in New York City in 1966 and grew up in Madison, Connecticut.
Rabbi Carlebach passed away three months later (October 1994) and never made it back to Israel to join the young musician.
Lloyd joined the band Reva L'Sheva in 1996, replacing founding member David "Harpo" Abramson.
They disbanded in 2004, although they returned for a concert at Zappa Jerusalem in 2014.

Acquiring drummer Moshe Yankovsky, they debuted at Mike's Place in 2006 and released two albums, Passin'over (2007) and Real People (2008).
After releasing two albums as Eliezer Blumen in the early 2000s, Lloyd recorded the album Higher Ground in 2004 with Ofir Leibovitz of the Israeli rock band Nikmat HaTraktor.
In 2012, he released the electric blues album My Own Blues and collaborated with singer David Orbach on the album King of Blues.
Lloyd released a second acoustic album, Lost on the Highway, through Blues Leaf Records in August 2013.
In 2015, he released his first internationally distributed album, the self-titled Lazer Lloyd, which included eleven of his own original songs and a cover of Otis Redding's "(Sittin' On)
In 2016, Lloyd released two CDs for sale on the road, Guitar Jams and The Moose is Loose (a live concert recorded at a Moose International Lodge in Kankakee, Illinois).
These road CDs were followed by a major 2017 international digital and physical release with his Freedom's Child album.

In 2020 Lloyd released his eleventh solo album, Tomorrow Never Comes, recorded in Nashville with Eric Paul (Townes van Zandt, Willie Nelson), in Wimberley, Texas with producer/engineer Chris Bell (Don Henley, Eagles, Eric Johnson), and in Memphis, Tennessee.

Lloyd opened for British blues guitarist Snowy White at a 2011 performance in Tel Aviv.

After moving to New York in the early 1990s, the band recorded a demo for Atlantic Records, who subsequently offered Lloyd a chance to record a solo record in Nashville, Tennessee with producer Garry Tallent of the E Street Band.
They played at a 1982 battle of the bands at Daniel Hand High School and toured throughout Connecticut, New York, and New Jersey, including opening for Michael Bolton at Toad's Place in New Haven.
His first band formed in his teens, Legacy, played covers of 1950s rock and roll.

Lazer cites B. B. King speaking in a master class about keeping his large band together for many years by looking for good people first and considering their musicianship second as a source of inspiration to him as a young man."
During this time, he also opened for artists like Prince, Johnny Winter, and Randy Brecker.
Rabbi Carlebach passed away three months later (October 1994) and never made it back to Israel to join the young musician.
After releasing two albums as Eliezer Blumen in the early 2000s, Lloyd recorded the album Higher Ground in 2004 with Ofir Leibovitz of the Israeli rock band Nikmat HaTraktor.

That same year, Lloyd released three new albums: the all-Hebrew album Haneshama, the acoustic album Lazer Lloyd Unplugged, and the live album Blues in Tel Aviv, as well as a concert DVD called Lazer Lloyd Live From Israel.

In October, as part of the Jewish Unity Music Project, he released a music video called "Ha'am Sheli" ("My People"), featuring vocals from Israeli singers Gad Elbaz, Shlomo Katz, Aharon Razel, and Naftali Kalfa.
The following summer, he embarked on a North American tour, including a Canadian tour with members of the Downchild Blues Band and a US tour with members of the Chicago Blues Kings.
The Freedom's Child album gained 150 points on the Americana Music Association chart in the first 28 days after release.

In 2020 Lloyd released his eleventh solo album, Tomorrow Never Comes, recorded in Nashville with Eric Paul (Townes van Zandt, Willie Nelson), in Wimberley, Texas with producer/engineer Chris Bell (Don Henley, Eagles, Eric Johnson), and in Memphis, Tennessee.
